which means that \Vect{x}_{\EuScript{S}} = (x_1,\dots ,x_n). Thus our original description of a vector in \RNr[n] uses the coordinate vector of \Vect{x} with respect to the standard basis of \RNr[n]. Whenever we are working only with the standard basis of \RNr[n], we will continue to write \Vect{x} instead of \Vect{x}_{\EuScript{S}}, as this will not cause any confusion.
